name: Synchronisation de Google Drive avec la base de données vectorielle contextuelle Supabase pour les applications RAG
description:
# Résumé du flux de travail

### Cette automatisation maintient votre base de données vectorielle Supabase synchronisée avec les documents stockés dans Google Drive, tout en rendant les données contextuelles et basées sur des vecteurs pour une meilleure récupération.

### Lorsqu'un fichier est ajouté ou modifié, le flux de travail extrait son texte, le divise en morceaux plus petits et enrichit chaque morceau avec des métadonnées contextuelles (telles que des résumés et des détails sur le document). Il génère ensuite des embeddings en utilisant OpenAI et stocke à la fois les données vectorielles et les métadonnées dans Supabase. Si un fichier change, les anciens enregistrements sont remplacés par un contenu mis à jour et contextualisé.

### Le résultat est une base de données vectorielle continuellement mise à jour et consciente du contexte, permettant une recherche et une récupération hybrides très précises.


# Pour configurer

## 1. Connecter Google Drive
•	Créez un dossier Google Drive à surveiller.
•	Connectez votre compte Google Drive dans n8n et autorisez l'accès.
•	Pointez le nœud de déclenchement Google Drive vers ce dossier (les fichiers nouveaux/modifiés déclenchent le flux).

## 2. Configurer Supabase
•	Veuillez vous référer à la note autocollante de configuration de Supabase.

## 3. Connecter OpenAI (ou votre modèle d'embedding)
•	Ajoutez votre clé API OpenAI dans les identifiants n8n.

options.systemMessage:
Only generate answers based on the results from the connected database. Do no under any circumstance, get answers from anywhere else.
for every query check the database to see if you can find an answer. If you can not or are not sure, then say 'Sorry, I don’t know'. Never come up with answers. Only get answers from the database

parameters.description: Call this tool to get knowledge from our vector database

parameters.content: ### Watch GD folder
### Set Text
### Generate Hash based on the text. If text changes we have a different hash
### Search the record manager to see if we have any files in the database, that have the same file id. If it does, it will return the hash
### Compare the Hash from generated hash and (if it exists) hash from record manager search to determine if file exists or not and if modified
### If the doc is modified, we delete all the vectors related to that google id and update record manager id and hash
### Create summary of document for metadata
### Set text to send to sub-workflow
### Watch GD Trash folder
### Search record manager on corresponding GD file id
### if records exist for this id or not
### Delete records from supabase
### Delete file from GD
## Query Seach Supabase Database Tool with workflow
### Set up data

## Setting up Supabase


### Create a project, and fill in the details as guided by Supabase.  On the left hand side, you will find the Project Overview section. Scroll down to connecting your project section and you will find the url and api key, which you can place in the credentials section or in the create new credentials in a supabase node.





## Setting up the Hybrid Search in Supabase
### You can learn more about hybrid search here: https://supabase.com/docs/guides/ai/hybrid-search

### Go to the SQL Editor tab, and delete the existing code. First we will create the documents for the Hybrid Search called documentsHS. Find the code in a note in this workflow to the left of this sticky note. Copy & paste the code in the SQL Editor and click run. You will get a message saying pg_notify. The documentsHS is complete. Now delete the code and copy paste the code for the record manager called record_managerHS in the sticky note on the left. You will get a message saying Success. No Rows Returned. You have now created the tables for the hybrid search. 

## To call the hybrid search, we will use the edge function.
### To create the edge function, go to the edge function (left hand side bar), click deploy a new function, and select Via AI Assistant.  Paste "Create a new edge function that calls on the match_documentshs_hybrid so it can be called through API". This will create your edge function and you can click on deploy to deploy it. In the details section, you will find the endpoint URL that you can paste into the URL in the HTTP Request (called Edge Function). Make sure to copy the Bearer YOUR_API_KEY as well and create a Header Auth to store it. You will find that in the Generic Auth Type under Header Auth. That will go in the Value section and the word 'Authorization' in the Name. You have now successfully completed the setup for the hybrid search.

# documentHS


-- Extensions
create extension if not exists vector;
create extension if not exists pg_trgm;

-- Table
create table if not exists documentsHS (
  id bigserial primary key,
  content text,
  metadata jsonb,
  embedding vector(1536),
  tokens tsvector generated always as (
    to_tsvector('english', coalesce(content, ''))
  ) stored
);

-- Indexes
create index if not exists documentsHS_tokens_gin
  on documentsHS using gin (tokens);

create index if not exists documentsHS_embedding_ivfflat
  on documentsHS using ivfflat (embedding vector_cosine_ops) with (lists = 100);

create index if not exists documentsHS_metadata_gin
  on documentsHS using gin (metadata);

-- ==========================================
-- Single HYBRID function exposed via RPC
-- ==========================================
create or replace function public.match_documentshs_hybrid(
  query_embedding float4[],           -- required; send as JSON array
  query_text text,                    -- required
  match_count int default 10,
  semantic_weight float default 0.5,  -- 0..1 (higher = more semantic)
  filter jsonb default '{}'           -- optional structured filter
)
returns table (
  id bigint,
  content text,
  metadata jsonb,
  similarity double precision,
  keyword_rank double precision,
  hybrid_score double precision
)
language sql
stable
as $$
  with base as (
    select
      d.id,
      d.content,
      d.metadata,
      (1 - (d.embedding <=> (query_embedding::vector(1536)))) as sim,
      ts_rank(d.tokens, plainto_tsquery('english', query_text)) as kw_rank
    from documentsHS d
    where d.metadata @> filter
  ),
  stats as (
    select max(sim) as max_sim, max(kw_rank) as max_kw from base
  )
  select
    b.id,
    b.content,
    b.metadata,
    b.sim as similarity,
    b.kw_rank as keyword_rank,
    (
      coalesce(case when s.max_sim > 0 then b.sim / s.max_sim else 0 end, 0) * semantic_weight
      +
      coalesce(case when s.max_kw  > 0 then b.kw_rank / s.max_kw else 0 end, 0) * (1 - semantic_weight)
    ) as hybrid_score
  from base b cross join stats s
  where (b.sim > 0) or (b.kw_rank > 0)
  order by hybrid_score desc
  limit match_count;
$$;

-- Optional helpers
create or replace function public.match_documentshs_vector_only(
  query_embedding float4[],
  match_count int default 10,
  filter jsonb default '{}'
)
returns table (
  id bigint,
  content text,
  metadata jsonb,
  similarity double precision
)
language sql
stable
as $$
  select
    d.id, d.content, d.metadata,
    (1 - (d.embedding <=> (query_embedding::vector(1536)))) as similarity
  from documentsHS d
  where d.metadata @> filter
  order by d.embedding <=> (query_embedding::vector(1536))
  limit match_count;
$$;

create or replace function public.match_documentshs_keyword_only(
  query_text text,
  match_count int default 10,
  filter jsonb default '{}'
)
returns table (
  id bigint,
  content text,
  metadata jsonb,
  keyword_rank double precision
)
language sql
stable
as $$
  select
    d.id, d.content, d.metadata,
    ts_rank(d.tokens, plainto_tsquery('english', query_text)) as keyword_rank
  from documentsHS d
  where d.metadata @> filter
    and plainto_tsquery('english', query_text) @@ d.tokens
  order by keyword_rank desc
  limit match_count;
$$;

-- Reload API schema
select pg_notify('pgrst', 'reload schema');

# record_managerHS code

create table public.record_managerHS (
  id bigint generated by default as identity not null,
  created_at timestamp with time zone not null default now(),
  gd_file_id text not null,
  hash text not null,
  constraint record_managerHS_pkey primary key (id)
) TABLESPACE pg_default;

parameters.text:
=<document> 
{{ $('Metadata').item.json.content}}
</document> 

Here is the chunk we want to situate within the overall document:

<chunk> 
{{ $('Loop Over Items2').item.json.chunks }}
</chunk> 

Please:
- Provide a short and succinct **context** to situate this chunk within the document for improved search retrieval.
- Return the **original chunk** exactly as provided unless a correction is necessary.
- If the chunk contains an **incomplete number, percentage, or entity**, correct it using the full document.
- If part of a **sentence is cut off**, reconstruct the missing words only if necessary for clarity.
- If the chunk is part of a table, include the complete table entry to maintain data integrity
- Do not add any additional explanations or formatting beyond the required output.

Fill in the following format:
[succinct context] : [original chunk or corrected version if necessary]

Your response should contain only the text that replaces these placeholders, without including the placeholder labels themselves.

parameters.content: ### Set up data
### Chuck document into multiple chunks based chunk size
### Add context to each chunk
### Set up text chunks and add timer so create limits are not reached
### Upsert into vector database.
# This is the Call My Sub-Workflow

# Workflow Summary

### This automation keeps your Supabase vector database synchronized with documents stored in Google Drive, while also making the data contextual and vector based for better retrieval.

### When a file is added or modified, the workflow extracts its text, splits it into smaller chunks, and enriches each chunk with contextual metadata (such as summaries and document details). It then generates embeddings using OpenAI and stores both the vector data and metadata in Supabase. If a file changes, the old records are replaced with updated, contextualized content.

### The result is a continuously updated and context-aware vector database, enabling highly accurate hybrid search and retrieval. 


# To setup

## 1. Connect Google Drive
•	Create a Google Drive folder to watch.
•	Connect your Google Drive account in n8n and authorize access.
•	Point the Google Drive Trigger node to this folder (new/modified files trigger the flow).

## 2. Configure Supabase
•	Please refer to the Setting Up Supabase Sticky Note. 

## 3. Connect OpenAI (or your embedding model)
•	Add your OpenAI API key in n8n credentials.
### Loop over each item, as more than 1 file can be placed in the Google Drive
### Download file
### Extract text from pdf
### Create new record in record manager since file is new and doesn't exist in database
## AI Agent to communicate with the database

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.

data.details: The Execute Workflow node can be used when you want your workflow to treat another workflow as a step in your flow. It allows you to modularize your workflows and have a single source of truth for series of actions you perform often.
